This file defines FFI-safe string identifiers (`StringId2`) for the `libdatadog` profiling library. It handles their representation and conversions with `StringRef`, prioritizing ABI and type safety for foreign function interfaces.
This file defines the `SetError` enum, a custom error type for operations related to collections, providing FFI-safe error messages and conversions from various allocation errors.

This file provides utility functions for safely parsing environment variables into various data types such as durations, integers, booleans, non-empty strings, and URIs, primarily for configuration purposes.
This file provides utility functions for UTF-8 string manipulation, including finding character boundaries and decoding individual code points, potentially replicating standard library functionality.
This file provides utility traits for `SystemTime` to calculate time until a deadline and for `HashMap` to compact its capacity based on a usage ratio.

This file provides an example of how to add custom message compression (using Deflate) to `tarpc` services by wrapping the underlying transport. It includes helper functions for compressing/decompressing messages and demonstrates their integration into a `tarpc` server and client.

Defines the `RetryBackoffType` enum and `RetryStrategy` struct, which specify different backoff methods (constant, linear, exponential) and parameters (max retries, delay, jitter) for managing retry logic in data transmission.
Provides a utility function to send HTTP requests to an endpoint with automatic retries in case of failure (e.g., network errors, timeouts, or specific HTTP status codes).
This file provides utility functions for processing and de-duplicating C header file definitions (typedefs and #defines), and includes a module for handling JUnit file attributes.
This module enriches JUnit XML test reports by adding 'file' attributes to testcase elements, mapping Rust test paths to their source files using Cargo metadata.

This file provides an 'ImprovedBuild' struct that wraps the `cc::Build` functionality, simplifying the compilation of C/C++ source files into executables or shared libraries, and managing linker arguments.
This README file provides instructions for fuzz testing the `libdd-trace-normalization` library using `cargo-fuzz`, including how to run the fuzzer, reproduce findings, and generate coverage.

This directory is intended to store snapshot files for tests within the `libdd-trace-utils` component. Snapshot tests compare current output to these pre-recorded files, helping to detect unintended changes or regressions. Although currently empty, it serves as the designated location for such test data.

This file specifies the gem dependencies and their versions for the Ruby project, including development and testing tools. It uses `gemspec` to include core dependencies and lists additional gems like `rake`, `rspec`, `standard`, and `pry`.
This Rakefile enables the Ruby `rake` command to be executed from the repository root, which is essential for the `publish-ruby.yml` CI workflow to function correctly.
This file configures the RSpec testing framework for the `libdatadog` project, setting up various behaviors for tests, expectations, and mocking.

This directory is reserved for local Cargo configuration specific to the `libdd-profiling-ffi` Rust project. Although currently empty, it can house files like `config.toml` to customize build settings, target-specific configurations, or registry settings for this FFI library. Its purpose is to provide a dedicated scope for managing Cargo's behavior within this Rust component.

This file configures commitlint to enforce specific rules for commit messages in the repository. It includes a custom rule to ensure ticket IDs, if present, are at the end of the subject line, and disables the default subject case rule.

This directory is intended to house Ubuntu-specific configuration files for the DevContainer development environment. As it is currently empty, it implies that no specific Ubuntu customizations are presently required, and default or parent-level DevContainer settings are being used.

This directory serves as a placeholder or configuration context for a development container setup tailored for Alpine Linux on an x86_64 architecture within the `libdatadog` project. It would typically house `devcontainer.json` or Dockerfile configurations for this specific environment. Its current emptiness suggests either a planned but not yet implemented setup, or that the configuration is handled by a parent `.devcontainer` directory.

This directory is intended to house configuration files for an Alpine Linux-based development container for the `libdatadog` project. Although currently empty, its existence within `.devcontainer` indicates Alpine is a supported or intended environment option.

This script automates the discovery, building, and uploading of Rust fuzz targets to an internal fuzzing infrastructure. It's designed to be used within a CI/CD pipeline, specifically called from GitLab CI, to integrate fuzzing into the development workflow.

This file defines the configuration structure for the Datadog sidecar, including IPC mode, logging, telemetry, and AppSec settings. It provides mechanisms to load these configurations from environment variables and serialize them back.
This directory is designated for tests related to the `libdatadog` library's packaging on Windows. It serves as a placeholder for validating Windows-specific distribution and installation processes.

This directory is intended to house Docker-related tools, scripts, or configurations for the `libdatadog` project. Although currently empty, its purpose within the `tools` sub-repository is to support Docker-based development, testing, or deployment workflows for `libdatadog`.

Sidecar & Service Management.description: Provides a resilient, out-of-process architecture that manages all data collection and communication, ensuring minimal performance impact on the host application and enhancing stability.

files.description: This file provides utility functions to convert Windows named pipe paths to and from `hyper::Uri` objects, enabling their use in a URI scheme.

This file is the main library entry point for the `datadog-ipc` crate, providing core functionalities for inter-process communication (IPC). It organizes modules related to transport, handles, platform-specific implementations, and rate limiting, leveraging `tarpc` for RPC.
This file defines an asynchronous communication channel based on Unix domain sockets, capable of sending and receiving both data and file descriptors using `tokio`.

This file defines a `BlockingTransport` for inter-process communication (IPC) in Rust, providing blocking I/O operations for sending and receiving length-delimited `tarpc` messages over a channel, including serialization and deserialization of items that can transfer handles.

This file contains benchmarks for measuring the performance of inter-process communication (IPC) mechanisms within the `datadog-ipc` library, specifically for `send` and `call` operations using Unix sockets.

This file implements a one-way shared memory communication mechanism in Rust, providing `OneWayShmWriter` and `OneWayShmReader` for concurrent and synchronized data exchange using shared memory handles and a generation-based update protocol.

Provides a blocking communication transport (`SidecarTransport`) for the Datadog sidecar service, including transparent reconnection logic and utilities for sending various sidecar-related requests (e.g., traces, debugger data, session management).

This file defines the `Liaison` trait, which provides an abstraction for establishing and managing inter-process communication (IPC) connections to a Datadog sidecar server, with platform-specific implementations for Unix and Windows.

This file defines Unix-specific mechanisms for Inter-Process Communication (IPC) within the Datadog sidecar, implementing the `Liaison` trait using both file-based Unix domain sockets and Linux-specific abstract Unix sockets to enable communication between the sidecar and its clients.

This file provides the Windows-specific implementation for inter-process communication (IPC) using named pipes for the Datadog sidecar. It defines how the sidecar connects to clients, listens for incoming connections, and manages shared memory for process identification on Windows systems.

This file contains unit tests for the `FLock` (file lock) mechanism, verifying its behavior across multiple processes and its proper lifecycle management, including lock acquisition, blocking, and removal upon release.
This file aggregates different limiting mechanisms for the `tarpc` server, including modules for limiting active channels per key and in-flight requests per channel.

This file defines an `Incoming` trait that extends streams of channels, providing methods for rate-limiting (e.g., max channels per key, max requests per channel) and concurrently executing incoming requests, particularly within a Tokio-based server.

This file defines structures for throttling requests on RPC channels. It provides a `MaxRequests` wrapper to limit concurrent in-flight requests on a single channel and `MaxRequestsPerChannel` to apply this limit to a stream of channels.

This file defines a mechanism to limit the number of active communication channels per key in a server, dropping new connections if the configured limit for a specific key is reached. It tracks channel lifecycle and updates counts accordingly when channels are closed.
This file implements a shared memory-based rate limiter for exception hashes, featuring a managed service that periodically cleans up inactive limiters to efficiently manage shared resources.

This file implements a robust and configurable mechanism for spawning child processes (workers) on Unix-like systems, supporting various execution methods like `fexecve` via memory files, `LD_PRELOAD`, or direct `exec`, and managing their environment and standard I/O.

This file contains integration tests for the `spawn_from_lib` functionality, verifying that worker processes can be correctly spawned and their standard output/error streams captured, particularly when the 'prefer-dynamic' feature is enabled.
This file implements Tokio-specific executors for the `tarpc` server, allowing it to concurrently handle incoming client channels and individual requests by spawning tasks on the Tokio runtime.

This file defines and tests a `tarpc` (RPC) service called `ColorProtocol`. It includes the service definition, an implementation (`ColorServer`), and a unit test that sets up a server and client to verify the RPC call for getting the opposite color.

This file contains unit tests for the `tarpc` procedural macros, specifically verifying the correct generation of service trait and server implementation code, including handling of future types, raw identifiers, and various method signatures.

This file contains unit tests for the `tarpc::service` macro, verifying its functionality with standard Rust traits, raw identifiers, and various asynchronous function signatures within a service definition.

This file defines a procedural macro that generates boilerplate code for RPC services. It parses a service definition and generates associated traits, client stubs, and data structures for inter-process communication.
This file contains integration tests for fetching agent information from a simulated Datadog agent. It verifies the functionality of `fetch_info` and `AgentInfoFetcher`.

This file defines the `RequestIdentification` trait and the `RequestIdentifier` enum, standardizing how requests are identified within the datadog-sidecar service. It provides mechanisms to extract and represent request identifiers like instance IDs or session IDs.

This file defines the `SidecarInterface` trait, which specifies the asynchronous RPC methods for interacting with a Datadog sidecar service. It outlines operations for enqueuing actions, managing sessions, sending traces, debugger data, DogStatsD metrics, and other service-related commands.

This file implements Rust procedural macros. It includes an attribute macro to generate request identification logic for `tarpc` services and a function macro to read environment variables at compile time with a default fallback.

This Rust procedural macro defines an attribute `impl_transfer_handles` that automatically generates implementations for `TransferHandles` trait for request and response enums derived from an input trait. It facilitates the transfer of system handles (like file descriptors) over IPC by generating logic based on `#[SerializedHandle]` attributes on trait method arguments or return types.
This file is an example demonstrating the usage of `libdd-telemetry`'s `TelemetryWorker` to send various telemetry data, including metrics and logs, to a local file endpoint for testing purposes.

This file defines an HTTP client trait and its implementations for sending Datadog telemetry, including a standard Hyper-based client and a mock client that writes requests to a file for testing purposes.

This file defines a `Scheduler` struct responsible for managing and scheduling events based on predefined delays. It allows events to be scheduled at a future instant and provides functionality to retrieve the next upcoming deadline.
This file defines a bounded, deduplicating data store for telemetry items, which tracks both all stored items and a subset of items waiting to be flushed.

This module defines the TelemetryWorker, which is responsible for collecting, storing, and processing various telemetry data (metrics, logs, dependencies, configurations) for the Datadog library. It manages the lifecycle of telemetry actions and dispatches them for further handling.

This file contains integration tests for the `send_data` module, verifying its functionality to correctly format and send trace data to a Datadog agent using various configurations and transport methods, including snapshot comparisons.

This file defines a `TransportClient` responsible for building and populating HTTP requests for sending trace data to a Datadog agent. It handles adding metadata, trace-specific headers, and the request body.

This file defines the `RuntimeMetadata` struct, used to store information about the language and tracer versions of an application. It provides methods to create and manage this runtime-specific data.

This file defines the `TraceSendData` struct, which manages a buffer of trace data along with its size. It provides methods to initiate a flush operation for this data, either asynchronously or by returning a future that can be awaited.
This Rust library defines the C Foreign Function Interface (FFI) for Datadog telemetry, including macros to generate C-compatible setter functions for telemetry configuration and properties.

This file defines the C Foreign Function Interface (FFI) for interacting with the Datadog telemetry worker. It exposes functions for managing the worker's lifecycle and sending telemetry data, including dependencies, integrations, logs, and metrics.

This file contains unit tests for the Foreign Function Interface (FFI) bindings of the Datadog span management library, verifying the creation, manipulation, and retrieval of span data, metadata, metrics, links, and events.

This file contains integration tests for the `datadog-sidecar-ffi` crate, verifying its FFI bindings for connecting to the Datadog sidecar, handling file descriptors, and registering application and telemetry information.

This file provides a Foreign Function Interface (FFI) for the Datadog sidecar, exposing its functionalities (like crash tracking, shared memory management, remote configuration, and sidecar communication) to C/C++ and other languages.

This file implements the self-telemetry mechanism for the Datadog sidecar, collecting and sending internal metrics about its operation, such as server activity, memory usage, and trace API interactions, to a telemetry worker.

This file serves as the main entry point for the Datadog sidecar daemon, orchestrating its setup, lifecycle management, client connections, and integration with telemetry and crash tracking services. It handles daemonization, IPC listener setup, and manages the sidecar's main event loop.

This file implements a watchdog mechanism for the `datadog-sidecar` service, monitoring its liveness and memory usage. It triggers an abort or exit if the service becomes unresponsive or exceeds its memory limit, and allows for graceful shutdown.
This file serves as the main library for the Datadog sidecar, organizing modules related to configuration, tracing, crash tracking, and service operation for the sidecar process.

This file contains Windows-specific implementation for the Datadog sidecar daemon, handling its entry point, inter-process communication (IPC) via named pipes, crash tracking setup, and generating unique identifiers for sidecar processes based on Windows security information.
This file implements the Unix-specific entry point and core logic for the Datadog sidecar daemon, handling inter-process communication, managing an AppSec helper, and integrating a crash tracker.
This file defines the `QueueId` struct, which serves as a unique identifier for queues, and provides functionality to generate new unique IDs using a random 64-bit unsigned integer.

This file defines data structures and logic for managing runtime and active application information within the Datadog sidecar service, including metadata, debugger tags, and remote configuration updates.

This file defines the `SessionInfo` struct, which manages session-specific configurations and runtime information for the Datadog sidecar, including handling telemetry, tracing, debugging, and dogstatsd settings, as well as managing the lifecycle of associated runtimes.

This file implements the `SidecarServer` which serves as the core component of the Datadog sidecar, handling client connections, managing sessions, and orchestrating services like trace flushing, telemetry, and remote configuration.
Defines the `InstanceId` struct, which encapsulates session and runtime identifiers used for tracking a specific instance of a service, along with its constructor.

This file serves as the main module for the Datadog sidecar's service component, defining its overall structure, session configuration, and the various actions it can perform. It orchestrates and re-exports sub-modules related to the sidecar's operational logic.

This directory is designated to store test fixtures or sample data specifically for the `datadog-sidecar` component. Although currently empty, its primary role is to provide pre-defined data sets for testing and validation processes.

Custom Metrics & Monitoring.description: Enables applications to send custom business or operational metrics to Datadog, providing accurate, real-time quantile estimation for high-volume data streams used in dashboards and alerts.

files.description: This README describes `libdd-dogstatsd-client`, a Rust client library for sending metrics to Datadog via the DogStatsD protocol.
This file documents the version history and changes made to the libdd-dogstatsd-client library. It serves as a record of all releases, starting with the initial 1.0.0 version.
This file implements a client to emit metrics to a DogStatsD server, defining enums for various metric types and a client for sending them via UDP or Unix sockets.
This file is an example demonstrating the usage of the `libdatadog` FFI for DDSketch. It creates a DDSketch, adds sample data, retrieves statistics, and encodes the sketch to a protobuf format.
This README describes `libdd-ddsketch-ffi`, which provides C FFI bindings for the `libdd-ddsketch` crate. It enables C/C++ applications to use DDSketch for accurate quantile estimation.
This file provides a C-compatible Foreign Function Interface (FFI) for the `libdd-ddsketch` library, enabling other languages to create, manipulate, and serialize DDSketch data structures.
This file serves as the changelog for the `libdd-ddsketch` library, documenting all releases, new features, and bug fixes over time.

This README file describes libdd-ddsketch, a minimal implementation of Datadog's DDSketch for accurate quantile estimation. It outlines its features, including data insertion, count queries, and Protobuf serialization.
This crate defines a minimal implementation of DDSketch, a data structure used to generate percentiles over streaming data with constant memory.
This file contains `prost-build` generated Rust data structures for the DDSketch Protocol Buffer definition, defining the structure of a DDSketch, its index mapping, and its data storage.

This directory is designated for Protocol Buffer definitions or generated code specific to the `libdd-ddsketch` component. It serves as a placeholder for data serialization schemas within this library. Its current emptiness indicates no such definitions are presently stored here.
This file is an FFI example program demonstrating how to initialize, configure, start, and stop the Datadog telemetry worker in C.
This C example demonstrates how to use the Datadog FFI to send telemetry metrics and logs through `libdatadog`, writing the output to a local file.
This file serves as an example or test for the `libdd-telemetry` library, demonstrating how to set up a telemetry worker, register and send metrics, and add logs to a file-based telemetry endpoint.
This file is an example program demonstrating how to build and send telemetry data, specifically DDSketches, to the Datadog telemetry intake using the `libdd-telemetry` crate.

This file is an example or utility demonstrating how to send an 'AppStarted' telemetry event to a backend using the `libdd-telemetry` crate. It constructs a telemetry payload with application and host details and sends it via an HTTP POST request.

This file defines structures and logic for collecting, aggregating, and managing telemetry metrics such as counts, gauges, and distributions. It handles the registration of metric contexts, recording of data points, and flushing of aggregated metrics.

This file defines data structures for representing and serializing telemetry metrics and distributions within the `libdatadog` library. It includes structs for metric series and distributions, along with enums for metric namespaces and types.
This module defines the health metrics emitted by the libdatadog trace exporter, including their types, naming conventions, and conditions for emission, to provide visibility via DogStatsD.
Defines the error types (`TelemetryError`) for the telemetry module, covering issues during client building and metric submission.
This file defines and manages telemetry metrics for a data pipeline, including API requests, errors, bytes, responses, and chunk processing, allowing them to be registered and accessed by kind.
This module provides the `TelemetryClient` responsible for building and sending telemetry data, specifically metrics related to data pipeline operations, to a telemetry worker/agent.

Manages and processes telemetry data for the Datadog sidecar, including metrics, dependencies, and integrations, utilizing a telemetry worker and shared memory for communication. It also handles caching for Composer package dependencies.

Crash Reporting & Diagnostics.description: Automatically detects application crashes, captures detailed stack traces and system state, and sends reports to help developers debug and resolve stability issues faster.

files.description: This file documents the changes made in different versions of the libdd-crashtracker component. It currently shows the initial release for version 1.0.0.

This README describes libdd-crashtracker, a Datadog APM library for detecting program crashes, generating detailed reports with stack traces and metadata, and asynchronously sending them to the Datadog backend using a two-process architecture.

This README describes the libdatadog crash tracker module, which enables libdatadog profilers to send crash reports to the Datadog backend. It details the module's components: a CrashInfo struct, a UNIX crash-handler, and a receiver binary, along with usage instructions.

This module provides a system for registering and invoking runtime-specific callbacks to collect stack trace information for enhanced crash tracing, particularly for integration with other language runtimes like Ruby or Python.

This file implements a crashtracker library that catches UNIX signals (or Windows exceptions), collects crash-related information, and uploads it to a backend. It operates with a two-part architecture: an in-process signal handler and an out-of-process receiver.
This module defines an `AtomicMultiset` for lock-free operations, enabling the registration and consumption of metadata by crash signal handlers for inclusion in crash reports.

This file defines the `ProcessHandle` struct, which manages a handle to a process, including its Unix domain socket file descriptor and optional process ID. It provides methods to create a handle and to finish/cleanup the process, ensuring the UDS is closed and the child process is reaped.
This file manages a thread-safe, atomic multiset of additional tags, providing functions to insert, remove, clear, and emit these tags for crash tracking purposes.
This file manages the registration and chaining of UNIX signal handlers, primarily for crash detection, and handles the setup of an alternate signal stack.

This file defines atomic counters to track the active state of various operations within a library, primarily for profiling and crash-tracking purposes. It provides functions to increment, decrement, reset, and emit these counters as structured JSON.

This file manages the spawning and execution of a child process dedicated to collecting and emitting crash reports. It handles forking, setting up the child process's environment, and initiating the crash reporting mechanism.

This file implements the core crash and panic handling logic for the libdatadog crashtracker, including registering signal handlers, capturing crash-related metadata, and dispatching crash reports in a signal-safe manner.

This file defines `SaGuard`, a lexically-scoped guard that temporarily blocks and ignores a specified set of signals, preventing their emission or handling during critical operations, and restores the original signal handling state upon dropping.

This file defines the public API for the crash-tracking infrastructure, providing functions to initialize, reconfigure, and handle post-fork setup for the crash reporter, including signal handling and alternative stack configuration.

This file contains functions responsible for collecting and emitting various pieces of crash-related information, including configuration, process details, signal info, metadata, and stack traces, in a structured format for the Datadog Crashtracker.
Manages thread-safe collection and emission of active span and trace IDs for crash tracking. It provides functions to insert, remove, clear, and write these IDs to a stream.

This file serves as the main module for the crash collector in `libdd-crashtracker`. It aggregates and re-exports core functionalities for managing crash handling, collecting various metadata like tags, counters, spans, and traces, and providing an API for the collector.
This module provides the Windows-specific implementation details for the crash tracker component. It serves as the main entry point for Windows crash collection functionalities.

This file implements the Windows-specific API for the crash-tracking and reporting system. It handles initialization, registers for Windows Error Reporting (WER) events, collects crash information (like stack traces and thread data), and uploads it.
This file defines data structures and associated logic for configuring the crashtracker, including stack trace collection options and receiver process settings.

This C file provides a function to translate OS-specific `si_code` values, used in signal handling, into a unified `SiCodes` enum for a crash tracker. This workaround addresses the variability of `si_code` constants across different operating systems.

This file defines data structures and conversion logic for handling Unix signal information (`siginfo_t`) in a human-readable format, specifically mapping raw signal numbers and codes to Rust enums for crash reporting.

This RFC proposes a new architecture for the crashtracker component to mitigate hangs and crashes by splitting its operations into watchdog, collector, and receiver processes, implementing timeouts, and a heartbeat mechanism.

This file contains a Windows-specific integration test for the crash reporting mechanism. It executes a separate application designed to crash, then verifies that a crash report is generated correctly and contains expected information.

This file implements a Windows Error Reporting (WER) out-of-process crash handler that acts as a trampoline. It identifies the PHP and Datadog tracer modules in a crashed process and forwards the crash event to the tracer's own crash handling callback.
This file implements a C program that acts as a receiver for Datadog crash tracking, processing crash reports provided via standard input.

This file manages the spawning, configuration, and communication with a separate crash receiver process. It handles process creation (fork/exec), inter-process communication via Unix sockets, and configuration storage for signal handler contexts.
This file provides a benchmark-specific entry point for the crash receiver, wrapping the main receiver entry point for performance testing purposes.

This module defines the entry points and overall structure for the crash report receiver component of the `libdd-crashtracker` library. It handles receiving crash information, configuration, and signals, primarily via Unix sockets or standard input.

This file defines entry points for the crash tracker receiver, allowing it to accept crash reports via standard input or Unix sockets, process them (e.g., resolve stack frames), and upload them to a configured endpoint.
This file implements a state machine to receive and parse crash report data, line by line, from a crash-tracker collector, assembling it into a `CrashInfo` object.

This file defines structures and logic for creating and uploading telemetry events related to crash processing. It handles sending 'crash pings' to indicate the start of crash processing and 'crash info' upon completion.
This file defines the configuration logic and data structures for sending crash and error reports to Datadog's errors intake endpoint, supporting both direct submission and agent-based reporting.
This file contains benchmarks for the `receiver_entry_point` function of the `libdd-crashtracker` library, evaluating its performance when processing simulated crash reports.

This file serves as the main entry point for running benchmarks for the libdd-crashtracker library, using the Criterion framework. It conditionally includes and executes benchmark functions, primarily for receiver components on Unix systems when the 'benchmarking' feature is enabled.
This file defines the `FlareError` enum, which represents various error types that can occur within the tracer flare component. It also implements standard error traits for this enum.

This file provides utilities for creating zip archives of specified files and directories, and for formatting these archives into a multipart form-data payload for transmission as a 'flare' to a Datadog agent.

This module provides the core logic for managing tracer flare functionality, including collecting diagnostic data and its transmission, with support for optional remote configuration to control these operations.
Integration tests for the `datadog-tracer-flare` crate, verifying its functionality related to remote configuration, log level management, and flare data submission to a Datadog agent.
This file defines the function responsible for generating the filesystem path for the crash tracker's Unix domain socket, adapting its location based on the operating system.

This file provides functionality to dump information about currently running Tokio tasks, including their traces, primarily when built for Linux with unstable Tokio features enabled. Otherwise, it returns an empty string.

This file provides common utilities for the `libdd-crashtracker` component, including functions to locate test directories and a safe wrapper for dynamically loading shared libraries and resolving symbols.

This file provides CXX bindings for the `crash_info` module, enabling a safe and idiomatic C++ API to interact with Rust's crash information data structures and builder patterns. It defines FFI-compatible types and wrapper functions for type conversion between C++ and Rust.

This file is an FFI example demonstrating how to programmatically construct a `CrashInfo` object using `libdatadog`'s crash tracker, including building stack traces, adding frames, and thread information.

This file provides an example C program demonstrating the use of the `libdatadog` crash tracking library. It initializes the crash tracker, adds metadata, and then intentionally triggers a segmentation fault to show how crash reports are generated.

This file provides a C++ example demonstrating how to use the libdatadog crash tracker's C++ bindings to programmatically build a detailed crash report, including metadata, process info, OS info, and a stack trace, then serialize it to JSON.

This README describes `libdd-crashtracker-ffi`, which provides C-compatible Foreign Function Interface (FFI) bindings for the `libdd-crashtracker` library. Its purpose is to enable cross-language crash tracking in applications written in C, C++, and other languages by exposing a C API.

This module provides FFI bindings for registering runtime-specific crash callbacks, allowing dynamic languages to provide stack traces during crashes. It defines types and functions to register callbacks for collecting runtime stack frames or complete stack trace strings.

This file provides FFI entry points for receiving crash data from a crash collector via stdin or a Unix socket. It formats this data into JSON and emits it to a configured destination, acting as a sidecar to safely handle crash reporting.

This file serves as the main library entry point for the `libdd-crashtracker-ffi` crate, organizing and exposing platform-specific modules and functionalities for crash collection, reception, and information processing.
This file provides C FFI functions for managing additional tags within the Datadog crash tracker, allowing tags to be added, removed, and cleared to provide context during crash analysis.

This file provides FFI (Foreign Function Interface) functions for managing active trace and span IDs within a crash tracker. It allows for clearing, inserting, and removing these 128-bit IDs, primarily used to record ongoing operations at the time of a crash, especially in `fork` scenarios.

This file provides FFI (Foreign Function Interface) for managing atomic counters related to crash tracking operations, allowing external C-compatible code to reset, increment, and decrement operation counts.

This file provides the Foreign Function Interface (FFI) for the Datadog crash tracker collector, exposing C-compatible functions to initialize, enable, disable, reconfigure, and manage the crash-tracking infrastructure.

This file defines C-compatible data structures and conversion logic for configuring and interacting with the `libdd_crashtracker` library via a Foreign Function Interface (FFI). It provides the external API types for the crashtracker's configuration and operation results.

This file provides a Foreign Function Interface (FFI) for demangling C++ symbols, converting mangled names into human-readable forms for crash tracking purposes. It uses the `symbolic-demangle` library to perform the actual demangling.
Defines the FFI-compatible SigInfo struct and provides conversion logic from it to the internal libdd_crashtracker::SigInfo type, facilitating signal information exchange.

This file provides the C Foreign Function Interface (FFI) for managing `StackTrace` objects within the `libdd-crashtracker` library. It exposes functions to create, modify, and manage the lifecycle of stack trace information across language boundaries.

This file defines the `ThreadData` struct for FFI (Foreign Function Interface) and handles the conversion of thread-specific crash information from the FFI representation to the internal `libdd_crashtracker` data structure.

This file defines the FFI-compatible `Metadata` struct used for crash tracking, including library name, version, family, and tags. It also provides a conversion mechanism from this FFI-compatible struct to the internal `libdd_crashtracker::Metadata` type.

This file defines a C-compatible structure for operating system information and provides a conversion implementation to transform FFI `CharSlice` types into native Rust strings for the `libdd_crashtracker` library.

This file defines the C-compatible `ProcInfo` structure for representing process and thread IDs in the crash tracker FFI, and provides conversion logic to an internal Rust `libdd_crashtracker::ProcInfo` type.

This file provides the C-compatible Foreign Function Interface (FFI) for the `CrashInfo` object from the `libdd_crashtracker` crate. It exposes functions for manipulating, enriching, and uploading crash information across the FFI boundary.

This file defines the FFI-compatible `Span` struct and implements conversion logic from this FFI struct to the internal `libdd_crashtracker::Span` type, primarily for marshalling span-related data like ID and thread name across the FFI boundary.

This file provides the C-compatible Foreign Function Interface (FFI) for creating, dropping, and populating `StackFrame` objects used in crash tracking. It exposes functions to set various properties of a stack frame such as instruction pointer, module base address, build ID, file type, path, and source code location.
This file is the main module for the Windows-specific crash tracker collector, likely defining its public API.

This file provides the C FFI (Foreign Function Interface) for the Datadog crash tracker on Windows, including initialization and callbacks for Windows Error Reporting (WER) to handle out-of-process exceptions.
This is a Windows-specific test application that initializes a crash tracker using `libdd_crashtracker_ffi` and then intentionally triggers a segfault to verify the crash reporting mechanism.
This module holds constants and structures that are shared between the collector and receiver components of the libdd-crashtracker.
Defines shared string constants and a default timeout for the Datadog crash tracker, used as markers for different sections of crash data.
Defines the `Metadata` struct used to store information about the crash tracker's library, version, family, and associated tags for serialization and deserialization purposes.
This file defines the `UnknownValue` trait, which provides a contract for types that can represent an unknown or default value, likely within the context of crash information handling.

Defines the `Experimental` struct, which encapsulates optional, experimental, or supplemental crash-related information such as additional tags, ucontext, and runtime stack details for the libdatadog crash tracker.
This file defines the `ProcInfo` struct, which stores a process ID and an optional thread ID. It is used within the libdatadog crash tracker to represent process-related information.

This file defines data structures for representing stack traces and individual stack frames. It includes logic for creating, manipulating, and populating stack traces with information like function names, file paths, line numbers, and module details, including demangling and symbol resolution.

This file defines the `Span` struct, which represents a unit of execution or context, likely used within crash information, including an ID and an optional thread name. It supports JSON serialization and deserialization.
This file provides a `TestInstance` trait for generating test data or instances, exclusively used within the testing environment.
Defines the `OsInfo` struct to store and serialize operating system details such as architecture, bitness, type, and version, including conversion from the `os_info` crate's `Info` type.

This file defines data structures for representing crash and error information, including stack traces and thread data. It also provides functionality, primarily for Unix, to process these stack traces by normalizing instruction pointers, resolving symbols, and demangling names.

This module defines the `CrashInfo` struct, which encapsulates all relevant data about a crash, and provides methods for its construction, enrichment, serialization to file, and uploading to configured endpoints.
This file contains C++ functions, classes, and namespaces designed to provide various symbol examples for normalization and symbolization tests, likely for a crash tracker or similar debugging tool.

This C file is a test utility designed to generate a program with large and potentially compressed debug sections, used to test the robustness of a symbolization tool like blazesym in handling address normalization and symbolization failures.
This RFC describes version 1.1 of the `libdatadog` crashtracker structured log format. It primarily introduces an 'incomplete' flag for stack traces to indicate missing frames.
This RFC defines version 1.2 of the libdatadog crashtracker structured log format, introducing an 'experimental' field for flexible data collection.

This RFC details the design, priorities, and architecture of the crashtracker, aiming to balance reliable crash data collection with minimal impact on the system. It outlines the collector and receiver components, discussing risks and mitigations for both normal operation and crash scenarios.

This document describes RFC 0005, which specifies version 1.0 of the Datadog Crashtracker Structured Log Format, outlining its motivation, proposed structure, and fields for reporting crash information.

This RFC describes how the crashtracker can emit runtime (language-level) stack information in addition to native backtraces, detailing the registration API for runtimes and the data streaming format. It aims to provide a stable contract for language runtimes to supply stack details for crash reports.

This document is an RFC (Request for Comments) proposing an update (version 1.4) to the crashtracker structured log format. It specifically adds an optional `mangled_name` field to stack frame entries to preserve original symbol names after demangling.
This document describes RFC 0008, detailing version 1.3 of the crashtracker structured log format, which adds an optional `comments` field to stackframes for richer debugging information.
This RFC specifies the payload schema for crashtracker errors ingested by Datadog, outlining the structure, required fields, and the mapping of crash metadata to ddtags.
This document defines the structured log format (versions 1.0-1.4) for crash information collected by the `libdatadog` crashtracker, serving as the authoritative specification for crash reports.

This file defines the `DemangleOptions` enum, which specifies different strategies for demangling symbols (e.g., complete demangling or name-only demangling) within the libdd-crashtracker-ffi component.
This file acts as the main module for the `crash_info` directory, defining and re-exporting various sub-modules that together constitute the crash information structure and associated utilities.

Feature Flag Management.description: Provides a robust system for developers to remotely enable or disable application features, supporting controlled rollouts, A/B testing, and dynamic user segmentation.

files.description: This README describes 'datadog-ffe', an internal DataDog library for Feature Flag evaluation, intended for use in tracers and DataDog services. It notes that the library is subject to frequent breaking changes before stabilization.

This file serves as the main library entry point for the `datadog-ffe` crate. It defines and exposes core components related to feature flag types and provides a module for rules-based feature flag evaluation.

This file defines the `EvaluationError` enum, which enumerates all possible reasons for errors or non-error outcomes (like a disabled flag or default assignment) during the evaluation of feature flags within the `rules_based` system.

This module serves as the main entry point for the rules-based feature flag evaluation system. It re-exports core components like configuration, evaluation logic, and data structures for universal flag management.
This file implements a sharding mechanism using MD5 hashing, specifically a `PreSaltedSharder` that distributes inputs across a fixed number of shards, with an option to pre-salt the hash context.

This file defines the data structures for representing the result of a feature flag assignment, including the assigned value, the reason for the assignment, and methods for type conversion and extraction.

This file defines the evaluation logic for rules and their conditions, implementing how various comparison, regex, membership, and null checks are performed against attributes in an evaluation context.

This file serves as the module entry point for the rules-based evaluation logic, aggregating and re-exporting components related to assignment, rule processing, and evaluation context for feature flags or experimentation.

Defines the `EvaluationContext` struct used for storing and retrieving attributes during feature flag evaluation, including a special handling for a 'targeting key' attribute. It also includes Python interoperability for creating context from Python objects.

This file implements the core logic for evaluating feature flags in a rules-based system, determining the appropriate assignment (variation) for a given subject based on configuration, rules, allocations, splits, and sharding.
This file contains benchmarks for the feature flag evaluation logic (get_assignment) of the datadog-ffe crate, measuring performance using both SDK test data and a single flag evaluation.

This directory is intended to store test data or fixtures for the `datadog-ffe` component within the `libdatadog` project. It likely provides specific input or expected output for feature flag evaluation test cases.
This file is a changelog documenting the version history and updates for the datadog-ffe component within the libdatadog library.

Defines `FlagType` and `ExpectedFlagType` enums for representing different data types of feature flags, including their serialization, deserialization, and compatibility checks. These enums are likely used in a feature flag evaluation or configuration system.

This file provides a simple wrapper around the `chrono` crate to define a `Timestamp` type as `DateTime<Utc>` and a utility function `now()` for getting the current UTC timestamp, abstracting away direct dependency on `chrono`.

This module defines a custom `Str` type, an optimized string representation built on `FastStr` for cheap cloning and flexible internal representation. It provides various conversions and trait implementations for serialization, display, and Python interoperability.
Defines a flexible `Attribute` enum that can hold numbers, strings, booleans, or null values, providing methods for type coercion and integration with Python data types for evaluation contexts.

This file defines the `Configuration` struct, which represents the remote configuration for a feature flagging client. It encapsulates the fetched flags and provides methods for accessing and managing this configuration.

This file defines the data models (structs and enums) for Universal Flag Configuration (UFC), including flags, variations, allocations, and rules-based conditions used in feature flag evaluation. It also includes a `TryParse` utility for resilient deserialization.
This file defines and exposes the Universal Flag Configuration (UFC) module, consolidating and re-exporting its sub-components like assignment logic, compiled configurations, and data models.

This file defines the data structures for a compiled Universal Flag Configuration (UFC) and provides the logic to convert a raw configuration from its 'wire' format into this optimized, internal representation for feature flag evaluation.

This file is a C example demonstrating the usage of Datadog's Feature Flag Evaluation (FFE) Foreign Function Interface (FFI). It shows how to load flag configurations, create an evaluation context, and evaluate feature flags with various types and handle results.
This file defines a generic, opaque `Handle` struct that manages ownership of a heap-allocated resource `T` for safe FFI (Foreign Function Interface) usage, providing explicit memory deallocation.

This file provides Foreign Function Interface (FFI) bindings for creating and managing feature flag `Configuration` objects from JSON bytes. It exposes C-compatible functions to instantiate a configuration from server responses and to free its resources.

This file provides the FFI (Foreign Function Interface) for creating and managing an `EvaluationContext` used in feature flagging or rules-based evaluation within the Datadog Feature Flag Evaluation (FFE) library.

This file provides the Foreign Function Interface (FFI) bindings for evaluating Datadog feature flags, defining data structures and functions to expose assignment results and their details to C callers.

This file is the main library entry point (crate root) for the `datadog-ffe-ffi` Rust crate. It defines and re-exports modules related to Foreign Function Interface (FFI) bindings for Datadog's Feature Flag Evaluation, including assignment, configuration, evaluation context, and handles.
This file is a changelog for the `datadog-ffe-ffi` component, documenting its version history. It details bug fixes, feature updates, and release notes across different versions.

Data Security & Obfuscation.description: Automatically identifies and redacts sensitive information such as PII, credit card numbers, and credentials from traces and logs to ensure data privacy and help meet compliance requirements.

files.description: This file is the changelog for the `libdd-trace-obfuscation` component, documenting its version history and changes.

This file defines structures and functions for applying regular expression-based replacement rules to obfuscate or sanitize data within Datadog trace spans. It provides mechanisms to parse rules, compile regexes, and apply these rules to specific span tags or resource names.
This file defines the `ObfuscationConfig` struct and handles loading various data obfuscation settings from environment variables for APM traces.

This README provides an overview of the `libdd-trace-obfuscation` library, detailing its purpose as a Datadog trace obfuscation library that handles SQL, Redis, Memcached, HTTP URLs, credit card numbers, and stack traces.

This file serves as the main library entry point for data obfuscation utilities within the `libdd-trace-obfuscation` crate. It exposes modules for obfuscating sensitive information across various data types and protocols like HTTP, SQL, Redis, and credit card numbers.
This file provides a utility function for obfuscating URLs by removing sensitive information like usernames, passwords, query strings, and digits within path segments.

This file implements a tokenizer for Redis commands, splitting a Redis query string into individual commands and their arguments. It handles various formatting, including whitespace, newlines, and quoted arguments.
This file contains utility functions for identifying potential credit card numbers within strings, using issuer identification number (IIN) prefix validation and the Luhn algorithm.

This file provides functions to quantize and obfuscate IP addresses found in peer tags for trace metrics, replacing non-allowed IP addresses with a generic 'blocked-ip-address' string while preserving whitelisted IPs.

This file defines the core `obfuscate_span` function, which modifies a tracing span's metadata to redact or anonymize sensitive information based on its type (e.g., HTTP, Memcached, Redis) and configurable rules. It ensures privacy and reduces data exposure in distributed traces.

This file provides functions to obfuscate sensitive data within Redis command strings by replacing specific arguments with placeholders. It implements various obfuscation strategies tailored to different Redis command types.

This file provides functionality to obfuscate SQL strings by replacing literals (like numbers, strings, and hex values) with '?' characters. It implements a non-rigorous parsing algorithm to identify and mask these sensitive values for privacy or security purposes.
This file serves as the main entry point for running Criterion benchmarks related to various trace obfuscation functionalities, including credit card, Redis, SQL, and IP address obfuscation.
This file contains benchmarks for the `ip_address` module, specifically testing the performance of the `quantize_peer_ip_addresses` function with various input strings.
This file contains benchmarks for the `is_card_number` function, evaluating its performance with and without Luhn algorithm validation for various credit card number inputs.
This file contains benchmarks for the `replace_trace_tags` function, which obfuscates or modifies tags within Datadog trace spans based on a set of defined replacement rules.

This file serves as a module organizing various benchmarks for different obfuscation functionalities, such as credit cards, IP addresses, Redis, and SQL, within the libdatadog trace obfuscation library.

This file contains benchmarks for the Redis command obfuscation functionality within the `libdd-trace-obfuscation` library. It measures the performance of obfuscating a variety of Redis command strings.
This file contains benchmarks for the SQL obfuscation functionality within the `libdd-trace-obfuscation` library, using various SQL queries as test cases to measure performance.
